prior_works.title: Kronecker Graphs: An Approach to Modeling Networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GraphMaster moves beyond classic structure-only generators like Kronecker graphs by producing text-rich, semantically meaningful node/edge attributes and enforcing structural consistency via LLM agents.

prior_works.title: GraphRNN: Generating Realistic Graphs with Deep Auto-regressive Models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: While GraphRNN pioneered deep autoregressive graph synthesis at the topology level, GraphMaster extends generation to semantically attributed graphs and adds multi-agent iterative checks to mitigate LLM hallucination and maintain structural validity.

prior_works.title: NetGAN: Generating Graphs via Random Walks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: NetGAN focuses on structural realism via random-walk–based GANs, whereas GraphMaster directly tackles the missing semantic/textual attributes problem and introduces agentic verification to ensure consistency under LLM generation.

prior_works.title: TextGCN: Graph Convolutional Networks for Text Classification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By evidencing the utility of text-attributed graphs for downstream tasks, TextGCN motivates GraphMaster’s emphasis on generating semantically rich textual node attributes rather than only graph topology.

prior_works.title: Open Graph Benchmark: Datasets for Machine Learning on Graphs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: OGB highlighted the scarcity and diversity gaps of large-scale graph corpora, directly motivating GraphMaster’s automated synthesis pipeline to provision data for graph foundation models in data-limited settings.

prior_works.title: ReAct: Synergizing Reasoning and Acting in Language Models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GraphMaster’s Manager–Perception–Enhancement–Evaluation agents operationalize a ReAct-like loop of reasoning, acting (tool checks and structural validation), and feedback to curb hallucinations and enforce graph constraints.

prior_works.title: Self-Instruct: Aligning Language Models with Self-Generated Instructions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GraphMaster adapts the self-instruct principle to bootstrap graph synthesis in low-resource regimes, iteratively refining prompts/outputs across agents to expand high-quality synthetic corpora.

synthesis_narrative: GraphMaster targets a core gap exposed by structural graph generators—Kronecker Graphs, GraphRNN, and NetGAN—which excel at reproducing topology but neglect the semantically rich textual attributes increasingly crucial for real-world graph applications. TextGCN demonstrated that text-attributed graphs can unlock stronger task performance, reinforcing the need for synthesis approaches that create meaningful node/edge text rather than only edges. Concurrently, the Open Graph Benchmark underscored the shortage and limited diversity of large, high-quality graph corpora, a central bottleneck for training and evaluating graph foundation models. To overcome LLM limitations (context, hallucination, and structural inconsistency) when creating complex graphs, GraphMaster draws methodological inspiration from the ReAct paradigm: it decomposes generation into agent roles that reason, act with tools/validators, and iteratively feedback to each other. This agentic loop, complemented by Self-Instruct’s iterative bootstrapping ethos, enables GraphMaster to scale synthesis in data-limited settings while improving faithfulness and constraint satisfaction over iterations. In combination, these prior lines of work—structural graph generation, evidence of the value of text-attributed graphs, recognition of dataset scarcity for GFMs, and agentic LLM control for iterative reasoning and verification—directly shaped GraphMaster’s multi-agent design for producing structurally consistent, semantically meaningful synthetic graphs tailored to the needs of graph foundation models.
